    for filename in filenames:
        print(os.path.join(dirname, filename))

source.91fc3d9d:
df.head()
original=df.copy()
def highlight_max(s):    
    is_max = s == s.max()
    return ['background-color: limegreen' if v else '' for v in is_max]
 
df.style.apply(highlight_max, subset=['HappinessScore', 'HDI',
       'GDP_PerCapita', 'Beer_PerCapita', 'Spirit_PerCapita',
       'Wine_PerCapita'])

source.4609e857:

sns.kdeplot(df['GDP_PerCapita'], color = 'r', shade = True, Label = 'GDP_PerCapita')
plt.axvline(df['GDP_PerCapita'].mean(), color='r', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=1)
plt.ylabel('density')
plt.title('Wine per Capita and GDP per Capita', fontsize =12)
plt.show()
source.cb290bc9:

plt.xlabel('Wine_PerCapita')
plt.ylabel('GDP_PerCapita')
plt.title('GDP_PerCapita VS Wine_PerCapita', fontsize = 12)
plt.show()
source.562d3a26:
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X,y,random_state = 42, test_size = 0.3)
source.1647e04a:
from sklearn.linear_model import LinearRegression
regressor = LinearRegression()
regressor.fit(X_train, y_train)
regressor.score(X_test, y_test)
source.9828977a:
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestRegressor
regressor_forest = RandomForestRegressor(n_estimators = 10, random_state = 42)
regressor_forest.fit(X_train, y_train)
regressor_forest.score(X_test,y_test)
source.46f296ee:
from sklearn.tree import DecisionTreeRegressor

regressor = DecisionTreeRegressor(random_state = 42)
regressor.fit(X_train, y_train)
regressor.score(X_test,y_test)
source.0be491db:
from sklearn.linear_model import Ridge
rid = Ridge(alpha=1)
rid.fit(X_train,y_train)
rid.score(X_test,y_test)
source.e7141a57:
from sklearn.ensemble import GradientBoostingRegressor
boost = GradientBoostingRegressor()
boost.fit(X_train,y_train)
boost.score(X_test,y_test)
source.48a794e8:
from sklearn.ensemble import AdaBoostRegressor

ada = AdaBoostRegressor()
ada.fit(X_train,y_train)
ada.score(X_test,y_test)
source.78f85fda: This is a correlation plot for the features. We can see that GDP_PerCapita is inversely proportional to all the other features. Let's drop GDP_PerCapita and observe the Correlation table again.
source.9d22bfcc: Did not expect to see Sub Saharan Africa at the top of the list.
source.8a1b0a14: ## Analysing with respect to GDP per Capita
source.d33f4f58:
North America, Australia and New Zealand are yet again at top for this category also. **There is a fairly big drop in rest of the regions for this category.**
Middle East and Northern Afrrica have the least consumption of Beer.
source.31dc9cd1:
Niger sits at the bottom. Norway at the top is almost 3 times the Niger value.
Mostly African countries in the bottom 25.
source.330c359e: The plot shows that most of the countries in the data have a Spirit Per Capita value greater than the mean.
source.0e2d8e13:
Qatar,Haiti and Comoros turns out to sit at the bottom.
There are a lot of Middle Eastern and North African countries which matches up to the Regions plot we saw earlier.
source.a2c9afd1:
There definitely seems to be something wrong with the GDP data for some of the countries in the dataset. A quick Google search showed me that Liberia does not have a higher GDP Per Capita than Sweden.

**With this in mind it makes no sense to look too much into the GDP Per Capita variable.**
source.07ea46a1: **Highlighting the maixmum values of each attribute in the data set**
source.373a9587: Norway sits at the top of the list. There are no South American and African Countries in the the top 25.
source.7e4047f2:
GDP_PerCapita has a much higher value than GDP per Capita. The red dotted line represents the mean value of GDP_PerCapita and green dotted line represents themean value of Wine_PerCapita. The mean value of GDP_PerCapita is more. 
Also the range of GDP_PerCapita is obviously more than the Wine_PerCapita.
source.d417fd47: The bottom 16 countries have the same type of consumption and are a mix of Asian, Latin American and Carribean, African countries, just as we saw in the Regions graph.
source.418edced: Surprisingly here, for the first time, an African Country is on the top.
source.1dd36e9e:
Western Europe, Australia and New Zealand, North America sit at the top.
Asia and Africa do not fancy Wine so much.
source.2ca47652: Hemisphere, Region and Country are not important features for our model so its better to drop these features to avoid overfitting.
source.8ac6a038: Australians, New Zealanders and North Americans are the Happiest people, while Sub- Saharan Africans along with Central and Eastern Europe are the least happy people.
source.c6ec3586: ## Wine per Capita vs GDP per Capita
source.76bd8d59: **Denmark is the Happiest Country.** It can be seen that a lot of American and European Countries are in the top 25 list. Countries all over the worls are represented in the list **except African Countries.**
source.b679215a: The plot shows that most of the countries in the data have a Wine Per Capita value greater than the mean.
source.11f58514: **No surprise to see France with the highest Wine Per Capita by a big margin.**
source.fdaaa3a9:
Australia, New Zealand, North America and Western Europe has the highest HDI. Sub-Saharan Africa haas the lowest HDI.
This plot is very similar to the Happiness Score plot we saw earlier.
source.1ebff8df: **The nation of Belarus is out ahead of every other country by a long shot when it come to the Spirit Per Capita. Russia and Haiti and tied for second place** there is a drop to the rest of the countries that follow.
source.66665cef:
Cameroon sits at the bottom.
Looking at the bottom 25 countries it seems as if Spirits might not be very popular in Sub-Saharan Africa
source.54f7d6d6: The plot shows that most of the countries in the data have a Beer Per Capita value greater than the mean.
source.76d94c1b: Most of the plots have a High HDI than the mean value.
source.90f12461: **Central and Eastern Europe sits at the top with Sub-Saharan Africa at the bottom..**
source.ead7e3fc: 76% is the highest accuracy achieved after using different algorithms.
